Key Laboratory of Coal Processing and Efficient Utilization Ministry of Education China University of Mining & Technology Xuzhou Jiangsu 221116 China The selective hydrogenolysis of CO bonds is critical for the effective valorization of lignin. Herein, we synthesized a series of highly efficient NixCoyAl-T catalysts by a coprecipitation-calcination-reduction method and evaluated their catalytic hydrogenolysis performance towards the CO bonds of lignin-derived aryl ether, using isopropanol as the hydrogen donor source. The results revealed that the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst displayed superior activity and its catalytic performances were strongly influenced by the Ni/Co molar ratios and calcination temperatures. The enhanced dispersion of metal particles and the electron transfer from Ni to Co in Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst facilitated the cleavage of CO bonds in lignin model compounds. Furthermore, the β-benzyl-H atom in 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE) also contributes to the cleavage of Caliphatic-O bonds. Under optimized reaction conditions (180 ℃, reaction time 2 h), PPE was completely converted over the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst, and the yield of ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol reached 95.91wt% and 85.73wt%, respectively. These findings demonstrate that the NixCoyAl-T catalytic system holds great promise for the production of valuable chemicals from lignin under mild conditions. Introduction Increasing energy demand and limited reserves of fossil resources make it urgent to look for the substitute of energy [1]. Biomass, a green, clean and renewable resource, has received a lot of attention [2]. As an important component of lignocellulosic biomass, lignin contains large volumes of sustainable aromatic chemicals in nature, which can be used as a potential source for high value-added chemicals [3–5]. The complex three-dimensional amorphous structural unit of lignin is mainly consisted by three types of aryl ether bonds, i.e. β-O-4, α-O-4 and 4-O-5 [6]. Breaking these aryl ether bonds in lignin is essential to depolymerize lignin into aromatic chemicals [7,8]. Cracking CO bonds via pyrolysis, hydrolysis, oxidation, and hydrogenolysis has been extensively investigated [9]. Among the reported strategies, hydrogenolysis is more attractive owing to its high atom economy [10]. Li et al. [11]. used heterogeneous iron catalysts to catalyze the conversion of benzyl phenyl ether (BPE) to phenol and toluene at 240 ℃ under 2 MPa H2. Yao et al. [12]. studied the cleavage pathway of diphenyl ethers (DPE) using a 0.5% Ru/H-Beta catalyst under 4 MPa H2. Saidi et al. [13] investigated the reaction pathway of anisole using Ni-Mo (20%−80%) NPs@IP catalysts under reaction conditions of 50 bar H2 and 15 h. However, the hydrogenolysis of aryl ether bonds usually require high-pressure hydrogen as the hydrogen source. The presence of pressurized hydrogen not only increases the energy input and equipment investment, but also raises a series of potential safety issues [14,15]. In this context, the use of organic solvents such as methanol [16,17], ethanol [18], and isopropanol [19] as the internal hydrogen donors for the transfer hydrogenolysis of CO bonds is safer and easier to handle. Moreover, the interaction between the solvent and catalyst is more conducive to the selective production of specific chemicals [20]. Hensen et al. [21] used a methanol/water mixture as hydrogen-donor solvent to achieve the depolymerization of lignin into monomers over Pt-based catalyst under an inert atmosphere. Shen et al. [22] studied the liquefaction behavior of alkali lignin over a Rh/C catalyst in an ethanol/water mixed solvent, and found that the addition of formic acid afforded to 91.5wt% yield of Tetrahydrofuran‐soluble bio-oil. Zhang et al. [23] investigated the transfer hydrogenolysis of CO bond over a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst using isopropanol as the hydrogen donor. They found that aromatic hydrocarbons and phenols were mainly formed after the cleavage of CO bonds. Solvent properties affect not only the efficiency of depolymerization reaction, but also impact the distribution of depolymerization products. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop transfer hydrogenation solvent systems for lignin depolymerization and identify the solvent-catalyst interactions in depth. Different solvents require matching catalyst systems to achieve optimal results. Noble metals such as Ru [24], Pt [25] and Rh [26] have excellent catalytic performances, but excessive cost limits their large-scale use. It is observed that transition metals such as Ni, Co and Cu can exhibit similar catalytic activity to noble metals by appropriate modification. Especially, the introduction of secondary metal can improve the activity of corresponding catalyst [27]. Supported Ni-Co bimetallic catalysts have been extensively investigated for their excellent activity and economy [28]. Zhang et al. [29] found that Ni-Co catalysts have high metal dispersion and strong interaction between metal and support, which significantly improved the catalytic performance. Tian et al. [30] investigated catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of guaiacol over a bimetallic Ni-Co/SiO2-ZrO2 catalyst, and found that the catalytic activity was significantly improved by the synergistic effect of bimetallic. Biswas et al. [31]. reported the depolymerization of alkali lignin catalyzed by bimetallic catalyst Ni-Co/AC catalyzed, and obtained significantly higher percentages of phenolic compounds in ethanol solution system. Zhou et al. [32] examined the hydrogenolysis of enzymatic lignin over Ni3Co1-based MOFs catalyst, and the synergistic interaction between Ni and Co shows excellent hydrogenation in the transformation of lignin conversion. Bimetallic Ni-Co catalysts had been applied to the hydrogenolysis of lignin owing to its excellent catalytic performance. Nevertheless, the interaction mechanism between bimetal is unclear using hydrogen-donor solvents under inert atmosphere. In this work, we prepared a series of NixCoyAl-T catalysts to catalytic the hydrogenolysis of lignin-derived model compounds and Kraft lignin (KL) using isopropanol as the hydrogen donor solvent under nitrogen atmosphere. The electron transfer from Ni to Co in Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst promoted the cleavage of CO bonds in lignin model compounds and the β-benzyl-H atom also seemed to benefit the hydrogenolysis of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE). Additionally, the pathways involved in the selective hydrogenolysis of PPE over Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst were proposed based on the reaction products obtained, and KL was selected to identify the catalytic activity of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 in lignin hydrogenolysis. Experimental Materials All reagents used in this work are analytical purity and used without further purification. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99%, AR), Al(NO3)3 ·9H2O (99%, AR), NaOH (99%, AR), 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE), diphenyl ether (DPE) and benzyl phenyl ether (BPE) were obtained from Aladdin Reagents (Shanghai, China) Co. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (99%, AR) and Na2CO3 (99%, AR) were obtained from Maclean's Reagents (Shanghai, China) Co. Furthermore, methanol, ethanol and isopropanol were purchased from Xilong Chemical and used as supplied. Catalyst preparation The NixCoyAl-T (x:y = 1:3, 1:1, 3:1, 3:0, 0:3, where x and y were molar amounts of metal salts added, and T was the calcination temperature) catalysts were synthesized by a coprecipitation-calcination-reduction method. Typically, 50 mL of solution containing 2.5 mmol of Ni (NO3)2 ·6H2O, 7.5 mmol of Co (NO3)2 ·6H2O, and 5 mmol of Al (NO3)3 ·9H2O was referred to as solution A, and another 25 mL of solution containing 6.25 mmol of Na2CO3 and 6.25 mmol of NaOH was referred to as solution B. Solution B was preheated to 55 ℃ in a 250 mL beaker with intensive stirring. Solutions A and B were dripped into a beaker with two individual syringe pumps. The pH value and temperature of the mixture in the beaker were strictly controlled at 10 ± 0.1 and 55 ± 1 ℃, respectively. After aged by stirring at 55 ℃ for 12 h, the obtained precipitate was separated from the liquid by filtration and washed with deionized water to neutral, followed by drying at 70 ℃ in an oven for 12 h. The resulting sample was ground into small particles and calcined in a muffle furnace at different temperatures (500, 600 and 700 ℃) for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 ℃/min, affording black powder named as Ni0.5Co1.5Al-T. Before use, the catalyst precursor was reduced at 600 ℃ for 4 h in a flowing H2 at a heating rate of 5 ℃/min in a tube furnace. Catalyst characterizations N2 adsorption at 77 K was performed on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ device, and the specific surface area and pore structure of the samples were determined with the brunauer-emmettt-teller (BET) method and the barrett-joyner-halenda (BJH) method. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of catalysts were recorded on the German Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.5142 nm) from 5° to 90° at a scanning step length 0.02° X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) testing was performed on the Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi using Al Kα X-rays (1486.7 eV). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) analyses were conducted on a Chembet Pulsert TPR type chemical instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. 50 mg catalyst sample was pretreated in argon at 200 ℃ for 1 h, cooled to 50 ℃, and then saturated with 10% H2/Ar. Subsequently, excessive physically adsorbed hydrogen was removed by purging with a helium flow rate of 30 mL/min. For NH3-TPD, the catalyst is pretreated in an Ar stream of 250 ℃ for 2 h and then cooled to 100 ℃. After the saturation of NH3 adsorption, the catalyst is purified with Ar for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed NH3. Finally, the catalyst is heated from 100 to 800 ℃ at a rate of 10 ℃ /min. Scanning electron microscopy (ZEISS Sigma 300) was performed to investigate the morphology of catalysts. Energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping was used to study the distribution of metal species. FEI Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopic (HR-TEM) were employed to investigate the metal particle size distribution on different ratios. Agilent 5110 plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was used to measure metal loading. Catalyst test and product analysis Catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin-derived model compounds were performed in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave reactor (AB100-HT) from Shanghai LABE Instrument Co., Ltd. In a typical experiment, substrate (100 mg), catalyst (20 mg), and isopropanol (25 mL) were added into the autoclave. After eliminating air by high-purity nitrogen for three times and pressurized to 1 MPa, the reactor was heated to the required temperature for desired time with the stirring speed of 200 r/min. All the experiments were performed in triplicate at least three times. The liquid product was separated by filtration, then the filtrate was analyzed by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS). The conversion and the yield of the product were calculated according to the following equations: Conversion = moles of substrate reacted / total moles of substrate × 100 (%) Yield = moles of product / total moles of substrate × 100 (%) Results and discussion Catalyst characterization Different characterizations of the catalysts were performed in order to evaluate the effect of catalyst performance on the hydrogenolysis reaction. Firstly, the textural properties of NixCoyAl-600 catalysts were evaluated using N2 adsorption-desorption (Fig. S1). The specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore size of the catalysts are shown in Table S1. The specific surface area of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst reached 74.59 m2⋅g − 1 with the total pore volume of 51.01 cm3⋅g − 1. The porous structure may be favorable for the dispersion of metal sites [33]. Comparatively, the surface areas of Ni1Co1Al-600 and Ni1.5Co0.5Al-600 catalysts were slightly smaller than that of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600, and the total pore volume also showed the same trend. The specific surface area and pore size of the catalysts decreased slightly with increasing of Ni loading, which is mainly due to the blockage of pores in the catalyst [34]. Therefore, the adjustment of Ni and Co ratio is beneficial for the favorable pores and specific surface area, leading to the formation of more active sites. XRD patterns of NixCoyAl-600 catalysts and their precursors are shown in Fig. 1 . The metal Ni and Co existed mainly in the form of oxides before reduction (Fig. 1a). Compared with Ni2Al, the signal intensity of the catalyst precursors decreases when the Co atom was introduced, which is due to the fact that Co atoms inhibit the agglomeration of metal Ni particles and improve the dispersion of metal Ni [32]. Due to the similar crystal structure of Ni and Co, the peak position assigned to cubic structure is the same [35]. The diffraction peaks indexed to Ni in NixCoyAl-600 samples gradually shift with the increasing of Co content, which results from the change of Ni lattice induced by the addition of Co. The lattice change promotes the formation of alloy phase and enhances the interaction between the metals [36]. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks of NiCo2O4 (PDF#20–0781) can be observed after the introduce of Co atom, while its crystalline phase is prone to form Ni-Co alloy phase during the reduction process [37,38]. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks of Al crystal were not detected in Fig. 1a, indicating that Al existed uniformly in an amorphous state [39]. No diffraction peaks of Ni and Co oxides were observed in the XRD pattern of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 precursor after calcination, indicating the presence of small amounts of single Ni and Co oxides. Uniform dispersion in the Al support or formation of bimetallic oxides of Ni and Co elements, which also facilitates the Ni-Co alloy phase [40]. As shown in Fig. 1c, the peaks at 44.5°, 51.8°and 76.3° are attributed to the (111), (200) and (220) face-centered cubic crystalline phases of metal Ni (PDF#04–0850). With the increase of Co content, the angle range of the diffraction peak for the reduced catalyst moves slightly, and the intensity of the diffraction peak gradually decreases (Fig. 1d), indicating that the crystal structure has been changed, which is consistent with the formation of Ni-Co alloy phase in the reduced catalyst [41]. The microscopic morphological characteristics of catalysts were examined through SEM analysis. Fig. 2a showed that Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 exhibited a rugged surface morphology and dispersed particles, and Ni, Co and Al elements are uniformly dispersed on the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst (Fig. 2b). In Fig. S2, Ni1Co1Al-600 catalyst exhibited a layered structure, but the layered structure gradually disappeared with the continuous increase of Ni content due to the tendency of agglomeration at higher Ni content. It was attributed to the fact that the change of Ni/Co molar ratio affects the morphological structure of the catalysts. Fig. 2c showed that the particle size of the prepared Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst is about 16.82 nm, which is smaller than other prepared catalysts (Fig. S3). It is noteworthy that the introduction of an appropriate Co content can promote the dispersion of Ni. It might originate from the interaction between Ni and Co, which is the geometric and stabilization effect in bimetallic catalysts [42]. HRTEM images of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst (Fig. 2d) showed that the lattice stripe spacing is 0.204 nm, corresponding to the (111) crystal plane of Ni-Co alloy phase [43]. The results of SEM-EDS atomic percentage (Fig. S4) showed that the content of Ni and Co in Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 are 13.26% and 38.22%, respectively, which were consistent with the ICP-OES results (Table S1) and theoretical calculated values of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600. H2-TPR was used to test the redox behavior of metals and interaction between Ni and Co. In Fig. 3 , the Ni2Al-600 catalyst has three different reduction peaks. The peak at 452 ℃ corresponds to the reduction of NiO to monomer Ni. The peaks near 624 ℃ and 712 ℃ were related to the reduction of octahedral coordinated nickel ions and tetrahedral coordinated nickel ions with strong support interaction, respectively [44,45]. In the case of Co2Al-600, apart from a relatively small peak at 434 ℃ associated with the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO, there is another main reduction peak at 715 ℃ originating from the reduction of CoO to Co [46,47]. Compared with the monometallic catalysts, the reduction temperature of Co in the catalysts shifted to a lower temperature region after the introduction of metallic Ni, confirming the interaction between Ni and Co. In other words, the strong interaction between Co and Ni enables the formation of NiCo2O4, which can simplify the reduction behavior of metal species [48]. The acidities of the catalyst were determined by NH3-TPD (Fig. 3b). Generally, the acidity strength measured by NH3-TPD was classified into three types: weak (T<300 ℃), medium (300 ℃<T<500 ℃) and strong (T>500 ℃) acidity [49]. Compared with Ni2Al catalyst, the strong acidic sites on NixCoyAl catalysts increased with the content of Co, which indicated that the interaction between Ni and Co existed, and this interaction significantly affected the acidic site distribution on the catalysts [50]. Moreover, the reduced Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst appears a significant NH3 desorption peak at 660 ℃, which demonstrated that the catalyst contains substantial amounts of strongly acidic sites, and doping Ni with Co enhances the strength of the strong acid. Acidic sites on the catalysts may be generated by the interaction of metals with the support or metal-metal during the calcination and reduction steps, which function as active sites in the reaction process and promote the hydrogenolysis of CO bonds [14]. XPS was further performed to elucidate interaction between Ni and Co species in the bimetallic catalyst. Fig. 4 and Table S2 represented the XPS spectra and the corresponding binding energies of NixCoyAl-600 catalysts. In Fig. 4a, the Co2p spectrum of these catalysts showed two spin-orbit peaks of Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2. The peaks at 779.5 eV and 796.6 eV belong to Co2+, and the peaks at 780.0 eV and 794.9 eV according to Co3+. Furthermore, the peaks at 785.6 eV and 803.8 eV correspond to satellite peaks [34]. In Fig. 4b, the peak at the binding energy of 852.0 eV is due to the metal Ni. The most intense doublet (855.4 eV and 872.9 eV) can be ascribed to Ni2+ in NiO, and the second doublet (861.2 eV and 879.0 eV) may be attributed to Ni2+ in Ni (OH)2 [51]. The presence of NiO and Ni(OH)2 is due to the easy oxidation of the reduced Ni atom surface when exposed to air in the presence of water, resulting in the formation of Ni oxides and hydroxides [52]. No peak of singlet nickel was detected in the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst, which may probably due to the low content of nickel and the formation of surface nickel oxide species (NiO) by exposure to air [53]. The survey spectra of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 (Fig. S5) revealed that these catalysts are composed of Co, Ni, O and Al, which is consistent well with the SEM-EDX elemental results (Fig. S4). Compared with Ni2Al-600 and Co2Al-600 catalysts, the electron binding energy of Ni2p shifted to higher potentials with the increase of Ni content in NixCoyAl-600 catalysts, while the binding energy of Co2p showed a decreasing trend, indicating the existence of electron transfer between Ni and Co [54]. The electron shift might be owing to the lower electronegativity of Ni and the stronger electron-absorbing ability of Co, resulting in the electrons transfer from Ni to Co to form electron-deficient Ni and electron-rich Co atoms. Electron-deficient Ni could increase the synergy with another electron-deficient atom, which is more favorable for the hydrogenation process [55]. Catalytic hydrogenolysis of PPE It is well known that β-O-4 linkages account for the highest proportion of naturel lignin [56]. Therefore, PPE was chosen to evaluate the activity of different catalysts, and the conversion and main product yields over different catalysts are shown in Table 1 . Initially, to confirm the indispensable action of the catalyst, the reaction was conducted without catalyst. It was observed no products were detected (entry1). Comparative experiments were conducted using monometallic catalysts. Interestingly, no reaction was observed over Co2Al catalyst (entry 2), while Ni2Al catalyst showed a good activity but a low selectivity for ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol (entry 3). When bimetallic catalysts were used for hydrogenolysis of PPE, the product exhibited an excellent selectivity (entry 4). Adjusting the molar ratio of Ni and Co, we found that Ni0.5Co1.5Al enabled to catalyze the complete conversion of PPE into ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol (entry 5 and 6). The improved selectivity of the target product may be attributed to the synergistic effect of Ni-Co alloy site and acid sites. To further investigate the effect of doping other metals on the activity of Ni-based bimetallic catalysts, Ni0.5Zn1.5Al, Ni0.5Sn1.5Al and Ni0.5Cu1.5Al catalysts were also prepared using the same method. Unexpectedly, no reactions were observed on Ni0.5Zn1.5Al and Ni0.5Sn1.5Al (entry 7 and 8), indicating that these catalysts were not suitable for the PPE reaction system. However, Ni0.5Cu1.5Al catalyst can catalyze the hydrogenolysis reaction of PPE with a low conversion of 56.54% (entry 9). These results emphasize the crucial role of Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst in CO bonds cleavage. In addition, Ni0.5Co1.5Al prepared by hydrothermal method has only 49.26% of PPE conversion (entry 10). Considering the higher conversion of PPE and higher selectivity to ethylbenzene, Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst prepared by coprecipitation-calcination-reduction method was selected for further studies. Calcination temperature is considered as an important factor affecting the catalyst performance. Table S3 compared the effects of different calcination temperatures on catalyst activity. The conversions of PPE are 27.90%, 100.0% and 22.63% over Ni0.5Co1.5Al-500, Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 and Ni0.5Co1.5Al-700, respectively, indicating the best catalytic activity of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600, while may be attributed to the smaller metal particles usually exhibiting higher hydrogenation activity [57]. Therefore, Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 was used as the catalyst to further investigate the reaction temperature and time. As shown in Fig. 5 , the conversion of PPE was negatively correlated with the catalyst to substrate. Meanwhile, the yields of cyclohexanol and ethylbenzene exhibited the similar trend, while those of phenol and 1-phenylethanol increased obviously with the rise of substrate dosage. When the ratio of catalyst to substrate was 1:1, only cyclohexanol and ethylbenzene were present in the product, which might be due to the increase of catalyst adsorption sites, promoting the hydrogenation process of the intermediates as discussed in the next section. Considering PPE was completely converted when the ratio of catalyst to substrate was 1: 5, therefore, 1:5 was chosen as the optimal ratio of catalyst to substrate for the current reaction. The effects of reaction temperature and time on the conversion of PPE were shown in Fig. 6 . The conversion of PPE increased gradually with increasing temperature from 160 ℃ to 220 ℃. At 180 ℃, the PPE was completely converted, and the yields of phenol and ethylbenzene were 14.29 wt% and 95.91 wt%, respectively. (Fig. 6a). In the absence of exogenous hydrogen, the reaction performance is heavily dependent on the nature of solvent [58]. Thus, the low conversion of PPE at low temperatures may be due to the low hydrogen supply efficiency of isopropanol at such temperatures, which limits the hydrogenation of PPE. Obviously, at the reaction temperatures higher than 180 ℃, the conversion of PPE remained unchanged and the yields of ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol increased slightly. However, GC–MS analyses showed that only a few of methyl isobutyl ketone and 4-methyl-2-pentanol appeared at 200 ℃, where their content increased significantly when the temperature increased to 220 ℃. These results might be ascribed to that the competitive adsorption between the isopropanol and substrate at higher temperatures. Fig. 6b illustrated that the conversion of PPE increased sharply with reaction time, reaching 100.0% after 2 h. Only the product of phenol hydrogenation, i.e. cyclohexanol, was detected, while no ethylbenzene hydrogenation product was found. These results indicate that the hydrogenation of aromatic ring in phenol is easier than that in ethylbenzene, which is consistent with previous studies [59]. Interestingly, only traces of phenoxyethylbenzene were detected, and intermediates such as 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanone and (2-phenoxyvinyl) benzene were not found. Moreover, PPE needs to overcome about 62.3 kJ/mol of energy to convert into (2-phenoxyvinyl) benzene, which is quite difficult in this catalytic system (Scheme S1). From the GC–MS results, the yields of cyclohexanol and ethylbenzene increased rapidly, while those of 1-phenylethanol and phenol decreased significantly. When the reaction reached 2 h, the PPE was completely converted, and the yields of cyclohexanol and ethylbenzene were 85.73wt% and 95.91wt%, respectively. With the continued extension of reaction time, the yields of ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol increased along with the decreasing yields of 1-phenylethanol and phenol. In summary, the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst is able to improve the product selectivity under a relatively mild temperature range. Active hydrogen produced from hydrogen donor solvents is essential for CO bond cleavage. As shown in Table S4, PPE cannot react in n-hexane without exogenous hydrogen (entry 2), so there is no self-hydrogen transfer pathway. When isopropanol was used as the hydrogen donor solvent, the complete conversion of PPE can be obtained at lower temperatures (entry 5), while when methanol and ethanol (primary alcohols) were used as solvents, the PPE cannot be converted at higher temperatures (entry 3 and 4). Isopropanol is usually more active than primary alcohols (methanol and ethanol) due to the higher electron release inducing effect of two alkyl groups compared to one [2]. It is worth noting that the conversion of PPE decreased in the presence of H2, probably due to the competitive adsorption of H2, isopropanol and substrate on the catalyst surface (entry 6). In general, the bond energy of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanone (227.8 KJ·mol−1) is lower than that of PPE (274.0 KJ·mol−1), and the cleavage of the β-O-4 bond in PPE begins with dehydrogenation to form 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanone [60]. However, there was an absence of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanone in the product of PPE hydrogenolysis, so we used 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanone as a substrate to verify the activity of the catalyst. Unexpectedly, the presence of PPE was detected in the product, which may be achieved by the keto-enol isomerization. These results demonstrated that the influence of substrate structure on the conversion of lignin β-O-4 model compounds containing ether bonds, and the main factor affecting the conversion is not the BDE value in the target ether bond original substrate. Zhou et al. [61] found that the β-benzyl-H atom in the substrate in hydrogen donor solvent was able to promote the cleavage of ether bond, generating phenol and enol acetophenone in the hydrogenolysis of PPE. Meanwhile, the β-benzyl-H atom in the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalytic system seemed to be favorable for hydrogenolysis with PPE as well. When acetophenone was used as a substrate (Fig. S8), it is rapidly hydrogenated into 1-phenylethanol [62]. Moreover, a very small fraction of phenethoxybenzene was produced during the reaction, which may result from the direct adsorption of the dehydroxylated PPE on the acid sites of catalyst. When phenethoxybenzene was used as substrate (Table S4, entry 1), very poor conversion of phenethoxybenzene and corresponding product yields were observed, indicating that the presence of Cα-OH also affects the Caliphatic-O bond breaking. In summary, a possible reaction pathway of PPE catalyzed by Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 was proposed (Scheme 1 ). Initially, a large number of isopropanol binding sites are present on the surface of Ni-Co alloy sites, and isopropanol adsorbs onto the alloy sites to produce active hydrogen. Subsequently, the Caliphatic-O bond of PPE is broken by activation of β-benzyl-H atom, which promotes its cleavage to produce phenol and enol acetophenone. The generated acetophenone is rapidly hydrogenated into 1-phenylethanol, and then 1-phenylethanol is dehydrated to produce ethylbenzene, while phenol is further hydrogenated into cyclohexanol. The electron transfer from Ni to Co also weakens the Caliphatic-O bond of the substrate intermediate and leads to the cleavage of the Caliphatic-O bond. Considering the high selectivity of ethylbenzene in the product, the direct cleavage of Caliphatic-O bond in PPE is the main reaction route. Hydrogenolysis of other lignin model compounds We further investigated the hydrogenolysis behaviors of several typical lignin model compounds, which represent the main CO bonds of lignin (β-O-4, α-O-4 and 4-O-5 bonds). As shown in Table S4, Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst also performed an excellent hydrogenolysis activity for these lignin model compounds. Similar to the PPE, the lignin derived dimers underwent CO bond cleavage and subsequent aromatic ring hydrogenation in the hydrogenolysis reaction. Increasing the reaction temperature appropriately resulted in complete conversion of both DPE and BPE, achieving 100.0% selectivity to the monomeric products. As depicted in Fig. S6, only benzene, phenol, and cyclohexanol were produced in the hydrogenolysis of DPE. It can be inferred that the Caromatic-O- Caromatic ether bond in DPE was broken down to form benzene and phenol, which are subsequently hydrogenated to cyclohexanol. Fig. S7 showed the hydrogenolysis of BPE over Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst, where phenol and toluene are the primary products. With the increase of reaction time, the yield of cyclohexanol increases while the yield of phenol decreases significantly, indicating that phenol undergoes further hydrogenation to cyclohexanol. Thus, the Caliphatic-O bond in BPE was selectively cleaved, because of lower bond dissociation energy of Caliphatic-O bond than Caromatic-O. It is worth noting that no dimer hydrogenation products were detected, and no deep hydrogenation reaction occurred for benzene and toluene, which further indicates that higher temperature is favorable for the cleavage of CO bonds. Furthermore, Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst tends to hydrogenate the CO bond when using isopropanol as the hydrogen source. Reusability of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 for the catalytic hydrogenolysis of PPE Under the optimal reaction conditions of PPE, the cycling experiments were conducted over Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst. Compared with the fresh catalyst, the conversion of PPE after the third cycle experiment was significantly reduced, and the conversion of PPE in the sixth cycle experiment was only 63.84%. In order to investigate the reason of catalyst deactivation, the recycled catalyst was characterized by XPS (Fig. 7 ). Compared with the fresh catalyst, no metal singlet state was detected in the XPS spectrum of the used catalyst, indicating that the oxidation of active components in the catalyst occurred during the recycling process. To investigate whether the oxidation of metal possibly contributes to the reaction as well, we chose water as the reaction solvent instead of isopropanol. The product was extracted with n-hexane and analyzed by GC–MS. As shown in Fig. S9, the PPE failed to react under optimal reaction conditions, indicating that oxidation of the metal reduced the catalytic performance of the catalyst. However, after re-reduction of the deactivated catalyst, the conversion of PPE was increased to 98.00% and the yields of ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol were also remarkably increased, which indicated that the catalyst could be recycled easily and the recovered catalyst could be put into use again after reduction. Catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin In view of the excellent catalytic performance of Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 for the model compounds, KL was chosen to identify its activity for the catalytic hydrogenolysis of real lignin in isopropanol under the reaction conditions of 240 ℃ and 1.0 MPa N2. The oil yield of KL hydrogenolysis over Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 was 24.14%, which was significantly higher than that of KL hydrogenolysis without catalyst (11.40%), indicating that effective depolymerization of lignin was achieved over the catalyst in the absence of external H2. As shown in Fig. 8 and Table S6, guaiacol was the main product of KL depolymerization in the absence of catalyst, while the compounds in the products obtained from lignin depolymerization over Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 were diversified, and 1,4-dimethoxy-2-methylbenzene and creosol were the main products. These results confirm that Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 can effectively catalyze lignin depolymerization using isopropanol as hydrogen donor. Conclusions A Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst for the selective hydrogenolysis of CO bonds in lignin model compounds was synthesized by coprecipitation-calcination-reduction method. The Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst exhibited remarkable selective hydrogenolysis activity using PPE as a model benchmark compound. The conversion of PPE was 100% under the reaction at 180 ℃ for 2 h with isopropanol as the hydrogen donor solvent under N2 atmosphere. Across multiple reaction pathways, direct cleavage of the Caliphatic-O bond in PPE was the main reaction pathway. 1-phenylethanol was mainly hydrogenated to form ethylbenzene, while phenol was hydrogenated to form cyclohexanol. Moreover, the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600catalyst also showed good performances and selective CO bond cleavage activities for a variety of lignin model compounds and Kraft lignin. This high-performance and economic catalysts have potentials for valuable chemicals production from lignin valorization. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenolysis of CO bonds is critical for the effective valorization of lignin. Herein, we synthesized a series of highly efficient NixCoyAl-T catalysts by a coprecipitation-calcination-reduction method and evaluated their catalytic hydrogenolysis performance towards the CO bonds of lignin-derived aryl ether, using isopropanol as the hydrogen donor source. The results revealed that the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst displayed superior activity and its catalytic performances were strongly influenced by the Ni/Co molar ratios and calcination temperatures. The enhanced dispersion of metal particles and the electron transfer from Ni to Co in Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst facilitated the cleavage of CO bonds in lignin model compounds. Furthermore, the β-benzyl-H atom in 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE) also contributes to the cleavage of Caliphatic-O bonds. Under optimized reaction conditions (180 ℃, reaction time 2 h), PPE was completely converted over the Ni0.5Co1.5Al-600 catalyst, and the yield of ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol reached 95.91wt% and 85.73wt%, respectively. These findings demonstrate that the NixCoyAl-T catalytic system holds great promise for the production of valuable chemicals from lignin under mild conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds in lignin model compounds and Kraft lignin over highly efficient NixCoyAl catalysts
